title: 111_hr3449
content: The Act is titled the "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act" and it establishes minimum periods of rest and recuperation for units of the Armed Forces between deployments. The "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act" sets minimum rest periods for units of the Armed Forces between deployments. No unit can be deployed for a covered military operation unless the time between deployments is equal to or longer than the previous deployment, with Congress recommending a minimum period of twice the previous deployment. Covered units are specified in the Act. The "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act" mandates minimum rest periods for specified units of the Armed Forces between deployments. Covered units include regular Army, Marine Corps, Navy, and Air Force units. No unit can be deployed for a covered military operation unless the time between deployments is at least three times longer than the previous deployment. The "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act" sets guidelines for minimum rest periods between deployments for specified units of the Armed Forces. Congress recommends that reserve components should not be mobilized continuously for more than one year, with a minimum five-year period between deployments for units supporting covered military operations. Covered units include Army Reserve, Army National Guard, and Marine Corps Reserve units. The "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act" sets guidelines for minimum rest periods between deployments for specified units of the Armed Forces, including Army Reserve, Army National Guard, Marine Corps Reserve, Navy Reserve, Air Force Reserve, and Air National Guard units. Exemptions to deployment limitations apply to special operations forces and units needed for redeployment assistance as determined by the Secretary of Defense. The President or military chiefs can waive deployment limitations for units of the Armed Forces if necessary for national security interests. Army and Navy members who voluntarily request mobilization can also have limitations waived by their respective chiefs. In this Act, deployment limitations for members of the Marine Corps and Air Force who voluntarily request mobilization can be waived by their respective chiefs. The term "covered military operation" includes Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom, including participation in the NATO International Security Assistance Force (Afghanistan). The term "deployment" refers to the relocation of forces and materiel to desired areas of operations, including staging, holding, and movement. A "unit" is deployable and commanded by a commissioned officer of the Army, Navy, Air Force, or Marine Corps. This Act will take effect upon enactment.
